0.question: I am a 23 year old male (73 kg 5'9) with no previous history of seizures until I had a seizure 1 month ago and went through all sorts of tests like CT, MRI, Echo test(3 times), Holter test, EEG(3times),Video EEG, Liver Function Test, Multiple blood tests and all came back normal.I was taking anxiety medications and my neurologists are saying i don't have epilepsy and the seizure was the side effect of the meds i took. But now my issue is i feel dizzy or disoriented whenever i play games for half an hour. l didn't have this issue before and I am used to flashing lights (i frequently goes to parties and concerts).I talked about this to my neurologists and they are saying i dont have epilepsy and this probably caused due to eyestrain. But today my screentime was short but when i started playing at night...after half an hour i started feeling disoriented (I play valorant and Apex Legends).l still have anxiety and dissociation issues btw. Any advice is appreciated.
0.answer:
It's great that you've been thorough with the tests and consulted with your neurologist. It's also important to note that while your neurologist has ruled out epilepsy, it's still possible that you may be experiencing some form of seizure disorder or other neurological issue that doesn't show up on standard tests. Here are a few things you might consider:

1. **Migration Aura**: This is a type of aura that occurs before a seizure. It can cause symptoms like dizziness, disorientation, and even nausea. These symptoms can sometimes last for a few minutes to a few hours. Since you're experiencing these symptoms after half an hour of gaming, it's possible that this could be a form of migraine aura, although it's atypical in its duration.

2. **Visual Snow**: This is a condition where a person sees a sort of 'snow' or static on their visual field. It can be triggered by screens and can cause confusion, disorientation, and even dizziness. It's more common than previously thought, and it's possible that your EEG might not have picked it up.

3. **Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)**: These are seizures that are not caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain but rather by psychological factors. They can often be triggered by stress, anxiety, or other mental health issues. While your neurologist might have ruled out epilepsy, PNES is still a possibility.

4. **Medication Side Effects**: Even though your neurologist believes that your initial seizure was due to the anxiety medications you were taking, it's possible that you're still experiencing some side effects from them. It might be worth discussing this with your doctor.

Given that you're still experiencing these symptoms and they're interfering with your life, it might be worthwhile to seek a second opinion or to consult with a neurologist who has a special interest in puzzling cases like yours. It could also be helpful to keep a comprehensive record of your symptoms, including when they occur, what seems to trigger them, and any other details that might be relevant.

In the meantime, you might try some self-care measures to see if they help. These could include:

- Taking breaks from gaming every 30 minutes or so to rest your eyes.
- Making sure your gaming area is well-lit and you're not straining your eyes to see the screen.
- Staying hydrated and eating a balanced diet.
- Getting enough sleep.
- Managing your anxiety through therapies like CBT or mindfulness, if you haven't already.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself and your body. It can take time to figure out what's going on and how to manage it. Also, it's crucial to stay in touch with your healthcare providers and let them know about any new symptoms or changes in your health.

Lastly, it might be helpful to connect with others who have shared similar experiences. Online forums and support groups can be a great source of information and comfort.

1.question: 25M, Caucasian, 172cm, 77kg, fit and athletic, do lots of sports, no previous illnesses or conditions, head injury when I was 4 years old with no obvious consequencesDuring summer of 2018, I had my first what doctors described consciousness crisis. We were about to go rafting and I was walking in my wet suit through very cold water while it was very hot outside. My friends said that I just collapsed down and fell into the water. Last thing I remember was walking and then I just woke up on the river bank with everyone around me. I had blood coming out of my mount because I bit my tongue quite badly. I had no recollection of what happened and I was very confused and had no idea where I was or what year it is. Was taken to a hospital and they did an ecg and xray of my lungs and head and they also ran a blood test. Everything was in good order. The night before I didn't get the best sleep and we also drank a couple of beers.Fast-forward 2 years and 7 months, celebrating new year with my friends. I had just 1 beer and took a couple of puffs of weed. We had a long and good sleep and the next day we went on a little road trip. Everything was fine up until the evening. I was sitting on a couch and my friends said that I just let out a heavy suppressed scream and I collapsed on to the floor hitting my head on the corner of the table (still got a little scar). Woke up after 10 minutes confused AF because it felt like time travel. They took me to the hospital and I hot a CT scan of my head and urine an blood test and again everything was okay. The next day I went to a neurologist and he ordered an EEG after a sleepless night and an MRI and once again everything was totally fine. He das prescribed me 50mg of Lamotrigin to take in the morning and evening 25mg each (50mg in total).Now for almost 3 years I had no issues. Important to note that before the first seizure and after the first seizure I have experienced almost every epilepsy trigger multiple times. I went to rave parties and raved for 12 hours straight with flashing light while drunk and hungry. Listened to loud music, had sleepless nights, smoked week, have been blackout drunk amongst other things.So I am incredibly confused as to why have I collapsed twice in this 2,5 year period.Does this count as epilepsy?
1.answer:
Based on the information you've provided, here are some observations and considerations about your experiences:

1. **Two Isolated Events**: You've had two isolated incidents, each separated by a considerable period (around 2.5 years), with no seizures or issues in between. This pattern does not typically align with epilepsy, which usually involves recurring seizures.

2. **Triggers**: Both incidents occurred in unique situations and you mention that you've intentionally exposed yourself to potential epilepsy triggers (flashing lights, loud music, alcohol, sleep deprivation, etc.) multiple times without incident.

3. **Normal Test Results**: All the medical tests you've undergone - ECG, X-ray, blood tests, CT scans, EEG, and MRI - have come back normal, with no signs of any brain abnormalities or signs of epilepsy.

4. **Lamotrigine**: You're currently on a low dose of Lamotrigine, which is an anti-epileptic medication. Presumably, your neurologist prescribed this based on your second episode, but given the normal test results and the lack of further seizures, it might be worth discussing with your doctor whether this medication is still necessary.

5. **Possible Alternatives**: While your experiences could still be categorized as seizure-like episodes, it's also possible they're attributed to other factors. For instance, heat exhaustion (the first incident was during a hot summer day), extreme fright or stress, or even less likely, other conditions like faint or drop attacks.

Given these points, it seems less likely that you have epilepsy, though it's still possible. It's crucial to continue working closely with your neurologist to figure out what's causing these episodes, as they may have insights or ideas that could help explain your experiences.

If your neurologist suggests further testing or consultation with other specialists, it's a good idea to follow through. Ultimately, a clear diagnosis can help ensure you receive appropriate treatment and can help you better understand and manage your health.

3.question: My husband (40M) had his first (that we know of) seizure - it was a tonic-clonic seizure - about a month ago. He had an EEG and is awaiting MRI.Before getting the EEG, his neurologist said he most likely doesn't have epilepsy due to his age and since he has only had one seizure. But after she received his EEG results, she said he does have epilepsy and needs to start medication. Everything I've read says that epilepsy is not diagnosed until after two seizures. I have also read that epilepsy is commonly misdiagnosed. I have been trying to learn about EEGs and epilepsy, but I'm not entirely clear on how they diagnose the condition. Is there a specific electrical firing seen that takes place that means it is absolutely epilepsy? Or is it just if you have an abnormal EEG then they guess it's epilepsy and not something else?I definitely have some questions for the neurologist, but I don't want to throw out the idea of misdiagnosis unless I have a basis to stand on. Any information and insight would be greatly appreciated.
3.answer:
I understand your concern, and it's essential to approach this situation with a thorough understanding of the diagnosis process. Let's break down how epilepsy is diagnosed, the role of EEGs, and the significance of a single seizure.

1. **Diagnosing Epilepsy:**
   - **Seizure History:** The primary criterion for diagnosing epilepsy is a history of at least two unprovoked seizures. A single seizure does not necessarily indicate epilepsy.
   - **EEG and Other Tests:** However, if a person has had a seizure and further evaluation with tests like EEG (Electroencephalogram) and MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) suggests a high risk of future seizures, they may still be diagnosed with epilepsy.

2. **EEG and Epilepsy:**
   - **Normal EEG:** A normal EEG result does not exclude epilepsy, as about 50% of people with epilepsy have normal EEGs between seizures.
   - **Abnormal EEG with Epileptiform Spikes or Sharp Waves:** On the other hand, seeing interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs), such as spikes or sharp waves, increases the likelihood of epilepsy. IEDs can be seen in people with epilepsy but are also found in around 2-5% of the general population without epilepsy, so interpretation must be done cautiously.

3. **Epilepsy Diagnosis After a Single Seizure:**
   - Some clinical scenarios may lead to starting anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) after a single seizure. These include:
     - A high risk of future seizures based on factors like brain imaging findings (e.g., a scar, malformation, or tumor), the nature of the first seizure, or the presence of epilepsy risk factors (e.g., Febrile seizures in childhood, family history of epilepsy).
     - A seizure type associated with a high risk of future seizures (e.g., tonic-clonic, myoclonic, or absence seizures).
     - The potential for seizures to cause injury or harm (e.g., in situations where seizures might occur in water or while driving).

4. **Misdiagnosis:**
   - Epilepsy can be misdiagnosed due to various reasons, including missing the actual seizure event, misinterpreting symptoms, or overlooking other potential causes. However, starting AEDs based solely on an abnormal EEG is not common practice, as the risk of side effects and potential drug interactions should be considered.

Given this information, it would be beneficial to discuss the EEG findings and the neurologist's recommendations with them directly. Ask about the specific findings on the EEG, their implications, and the reasoning behind starting medication after a single seizure. In some cases, it might be reasonable to seek a second opinion or consult with a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy (called an epileptologist) to discuss your concerns and the best course of action.

4.question: ale, (controlled) epilepsy, lamotrigine 450 mg a day, average height and weight. I’m wondering what the opinion is for a person with epilepsy to donate plasma? I was turned away once when I disclosed my epilepsy to the people there, but I’m wondering why. I’ve had 5 seizures in almost 20 years, the most recent being April 2021. I’m just wondering if there’s a legitimate, medical reason I shouldn’t donate plasma? Thank you :)
4.answer:
Donating plasma is generally safe for most people, including those with a history of epilepsy. However, there are a few reasons why you might have been turned away, and it's important to understand these before trying to donate again.

1. **Medications**: Some medications used to treat epilepsy can affect the plasma donation process or the quality of the plasma. Lamotrigine, the medication you're taking, is generally considered safe for plasma donation. However, the FDA has a list of medications that can affect donation, and it's possible that the staff at the plasma center was unaware of the specific regulations regarding your medication.

2. **Seizure Frequency**: The frequency of your seizures is an important factor. Having had only 5 seizures in almost 20 years, with the most recent one being over a year ago, suggests that your epilepsy is well-controlled. Most plasma centers will allow donation if seizures are well-controlled and haven't occurred recently.

3. **Side Effects**: Some people with epilepsy may experience side effects from their medications that could make plasma donation unsafe. For example, if your medication causes dizziness or fatigue, you might not be able to donate safely.

4. **Dehydration**: Plasma donation can lead to dehydration, which could potentially trigger a seizure in someone with epilepsy. It's important to stay hydrated before and after donating.

5. **Plasma Center Policies**: Different plasma centers may have different policies regarding donors with epilepsy. Some may be more conservative than others.

Before trying to donate again, it might be a good idea to talk to your neurologist. They can provide guidance based on your specific medical history and the medications you're taking. They might also be able to provide a letter explaining your condition and the safety of donating, which you could show to the plasma center.

In conclusion, while there's no absolute medical reason why you shouldn't donate plasma, it's important to ensure that you're donating in a safe and controlled environment. Always consult with your healthcare provider before donating.

5.question: I (27F) had temporal lobe epilepsy from about age 8 until I was 10, when I had surgery to remove the gliosis (and part of my right hippocampus?) that caused my seizures. Every medical questionnaire and intake form I’ve ever had to fill out asks me if I have a history of a seizure disorder and/or epilepsy, and I always check yes and have to explain to whatever professional I’m seeing that I haven’t had a seizure since I had my surgery.I still want to be honest on these forms obviously, but I’m wondering is it even relevant to my current health anymore?As a note, I had my drivers license briefly suspended once when I was 17 or 18 because the DMV found out I’d used to have seizures and needed me to provide a doctors note clearing things up, so it’s important to me to know when it’s actually relevant to divulge my history.
5.answer:
It's great that you're being honest and thorough in your medical forms, and it's understandable that you want clarity on when to mention your seizure history. Here's a breakdown of when and why it's relevant to divulge this information:

1. **Still Relevant:**
   - **Medical Care:** Even though you haven't had a seizure since your surgery, your history of epilepsy can still be relevant to your current health. Medications you took for seizures, the surgery itself, and the location of the seizure focus (in your case, the right hippocampus) can all have long-term effects. For example, you might have some memory or cognitive changes due to the surgery, or there could be other side effects from the antiepileptic drugs you took. Your current healthcare providers should be aware of these potential factors.
   - **Pregnancy:** If you decide to become pregnant, it's crucial to inform your obstetrician about your history. Some anti-seizure medications can affect the developing baby, and you might need to switch to a safer medication or adjust your dosage.
   - **Driving:** As you mentioned, your driving status can be affected by your history of seizures. In many places, having a seizure disorder can temporarily suspend your license until you've been seizure-free for a certain period (e.g., six months) and have been cleared by a doctor. Always follow your local DMV's guidelines for driving with a history of seizures.
   - **Insurance:** Some insurance companies may consider a history of epilepsy a pre-existing condition, which could affect your ability to get coverage or the cost of your premiums.

2. **Not Directly Relevant:**
   - **Many everyday activities** like flying, swimming, or working in certain professions are generally safe to do, as long as you've been seizure-free and have been cleared by a doctor. However, it's always a good idea to inform your employer or a relevant authority about your history in case they have specific protocols to follow.

In summary, while you don't need to mention your history on every form (e.g., a library card application), it's important to disclose it to your healthcare providers, during pregnancy, when obtaining or renewing your driver's license, and to your insurance company. Always err on the side of caution, and if you're unsure whether to mention it, you can ask the professional you're dealing with to advise you on whether it's relevant in that specific context.

6.question: 27 years old male Non smoker 73 kg 180 cm No other chronic illnessFor the past decade, I've been dealing with two distinct issues.- The first involves zigzag flashes across my field of vision, which are then followed by a mild headache lasting about an hour.- The second is an abrupt sensation of déjà vu or dream recall that leaves me feeling anxious and uncertain about my own memories.Both of these "auras" typically last around 20 minutes. I haven't sought treatment yet since these episodes occur infrequently—sometimes just once a year or once every few months.I'm unsure if what I'm experiencing is related to epilepsy or migraines?If anyone has had similar experiences, I'd greatly appreciate your insights.
6.answer:
Based on your description, it's possible that you're experiencing two separate conditions. Here's a breakdown of your symptoms and their possible causes:

1. **Flashes of light (photopsia orscintillating scotoma) and mild headache:**

These symptoms are often associated with **migraines**. Here's why:

- Flashing lights or zigzag patterns are a common type of aura in migraines, occurring in about 20-30% of people who experience migraines. This aura phase typically lasts 20-60 minutes before the headache sets in.
- The headache that follows is usually throbbing or pulsating, affects one side of the head, and is moderate to severe. It can last for 4 to 72 hours and is often accompanied by other symptoms like nausea or sensitivity to light and sound.

2. **Déjà vu or dream recall sensations followed by anxiety:**

These symptoms are less typical of migraines and could point to another condition, possibly **temporal lobe epilepsy**. Here's why:

- Déjà vu is sometimes a manifestation of temporal lobe epilepsy, though it's more commonly associated with migraines with aura. The sudden feeling of remembering a present situation as if it has happened before can be quite disconcerting and cause anxiety.
- Recalling dreams during waking hours can also be a sign of temporal lobe epilepsy. This condition can sometimes involve "false memories" or difficulty distinguishing reality from dreams, leading to uncertainty about personal memories.

Given the diversity of your symptoms, it's possible that you're experiencing both migraine auras and occasional seizures. It's also possible that your symptoms are related to another condition, such as **psychogenic non-epileptic attacks**, which can involve alterations in consciousness, memory, and emotion.

Given the infrequency of your episodes, it's understandable that you haven't sought treatment yet. However, if these episodes become more frequent or if you start experiencing prolonged seizures, you should consult a healthcare provider as soon as possible. A neurologist can perform diagnostic tests like an EEG (electroencephalogram) to help determine if you're having seizures, and other tests like an MRI to rule out any brain abnormalities.

In the meantime, keeping a detailed diary of your symptoms and their frequency can help you and your healthcare provider make an accurate diagnosis and determine the best course of treatment.

7.question: My partner (20M) has been having these ‘seizure-like’ behaviours for as long as he can remember (so assuming his whole life). There are 2 separate ‘actions’ which he isn’t sure are related or not.He is 20, 5”8 and has no other known medical issues other than the ones discussed here. He is pretty healthy otherwise and always has been including weight per age and hitting correct milestones etc. He is also not on any medication.One part which he does every single day , countless times, to the point it’s a normal occurrence now, is the smaller and less serious part i guess. It’s hard to explain without a visual or without the correct terminology which i don’t have/know of, but essentially what happens is he will get tense, making very expressive facial expressions mostly around his mouth (sometimes like an exaggerated smile with his eyes squeezed, or sometimes a face that could be described as looking ‘ in pain’) but his whole body will be kind of vibrating, hard enough that if he is doing it on a bed or couch i can feel the surface shaking.Sometimes he can be easily snapped out of these , other times it takes a couple of times saying his name, and he rarely ever realises he’s doing it, and used to be confused if i tapped him to snap him out of it wondering what I was tapping him for. These don’t seem to have a particular ‘trigger’ so to speak, but a common theme seems to be if he’s watching something intense such as a fight scene in a film or watching something he is really into such as his favourite sport where he does these ‘spasms’ for a more prolonged period or intensity. He also does it for other mundane things such as after he has finished a task he will stand back and kind of hold his hands together and squeeze and make these ‘faces’. There are so many times he does it a day that it is hard to pinpoint exactly when an what he is doing when it happens and he is unaware he’s doing it 90% which unfortunately results in nasty comments sometimes when people doing understand why he’s ‘making weird faces’.
7.answer:
Based on the description you've provided, your partner's symptoms could potentially be related to a condition called Paroxysmal Fibrillation or Paroxysmal Dystonia. However, please note that I am an AI and not a healthcare professional, so my response should not replace a medical consultation. I strongly recommend that your partner consults with a neurologist or a healthcare provider to get a proper evaluation and diagnosis.

Here's why these conditions might fit your partner's symptoms:

1. **Paroxysmal Fibrillation**: This is a type of involuntary muscle movement disorder that typically starts in childhood and can be triggered by various stimuli, such as stress, excitement, or even mundane activities. It's characterized by brief, involuntary, violent shaking or trembling that may affect various muscle groups and often involves the neck and facial muscles. The episodes can be quite intense and are typically asymptomatic between attacks.

2. **Paroxysmal Dystonia**: This condition is characterized by sudden, involuntary, sustained muscle contractions that cause repetitive, twisting movements or abnormal postures. It can also be triggered by various stimuli. Unlike Parkinson's disease, which causes a slow, progressive decline in motor skills, paroxysmal dyskinesias are episodic, meaning they occur infrequently and unpredictably.

Some common features of both conditions that match your partner's symptoms include:

- Triggered by intense emotions or mundane activities
- Involuntary muscle movements and facial expressions
- Unawareness of the episodes
- Interference with daily life (e.g., nasty comments from others)

To get a proper diagnosis, your partner may need to undergo a detailed neurological examination, brain imaging (such as MRI), and possibly an electroencephalogram (EEG) to rule out other causes. A proper diagnosis is crucial for appropriate management and treatment. If it turns out to be one of these conditions, treatment options might include medication, botulinum toxin (Botox) injections, or even surgery in some cases.

In the meantime, you can help your partner by being patient and understanding, and by explaining his condition to others to help them understand why he might behave this way.

Again, please encourage your partner to seek medical attention for a proper evaluation and diagnosis.

8.question: I have tc seizures about twice a month or so. I have recently run out of my generic keppra 3 days ago. I will not be able to get a new script for keppra until Monday. I do have my rescue medication (generic Ativan) which I have never had to take before. should I take this every 12 hours like I do my keppra?
8.answer:
It's important to follow the instructions provided by your healthcare professional regarding your rescue medication (generic Ativan). Here's how you should handle this situation:

1. **Contact your healthcare provider**: If possible, reach out to your doctor or epilepsy specialist. They may be able to provide you with a new Keppra prescription earlier or adjust your medication plan temporarily.

2. **Use Ativan as directed**: Ativan is a benzodiazepine that can help control seizures, but it should not be used as a substitute for your regular medication (Keppra) on a long-term basis. The typical dose for seizure control when used as needed is 1-2 mg, which can be repeated once after 10-15 minutes if necessary. However, follow the specific instructions given to you by your healthcare provider.

3. **Do not take Ativan more frequently than needed**: Taking Ativan every 12 hours like Keppra could lead to side effects such as sedation, drowsiness, and potentially dependence if taken regularly. Only take it when you feel a seizure coming on or if you've had a seizure and want to prevent cluster seizures.

4. **Stay safe**: During these few days, try to minimize activities that put you at higher risk of injury if a seizure were to occur. Avoid driving, swimming, or operating heavy machinery.

5. **Monitor your seizure frequency**: Keep track of any seizures you have during this time, as this information can be useful for your healthcare provider when they see you on Monday.

Once you're able to restart your Keppra, make sure to do so as directed by your healthcare provider. It's essential to maintain consistent treatment to help prevent seizures.

In the future, you might want to consider discussing a backup plan with your healthcare provider for situations where you might run out of medication unexpectedly.

9.question: 25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?
9.answer:
There could be several reasons why you're experiencing seizures primarily when you're tired or sleeping, and not when you're alert and awake. Here are a few possible explanations:

1. **Circadian Rhythm**: Your body has an internal clock that regulates many physiological processes, including brain activity. During sleep, this clock can cause changes in brain Wave activity and neuronal excitability, which could potentially trigger seizures in those who are susceptible.

2. **Sleep Deprivation**: Lack of sleep can increase the likelihood of seizures in people with epilepsy. When you're tired, your body and brain are not functioning at their peak efficiency, which could cause neurons to misfire.

3. **Hormonal Changes**: Both sleep and wakefulness are regulated by hormones. Changes in these hormones could potentially influence the electrical activity in your brain and trigger seizures.

4. **Brain State**: Different brain states, like sleep and wakefulness, involve different patterns of neuronal activity. In some people, these patterns might be more likely to trigger seizures.

5. **Medication**: If you're on anti-epileptic medication, its effectiveness might decrease as you become more tired. Some anti-epileptic drugs can affectleep quality and may need to be adjusted based on your sleep patterns.

6. **Individual Susceptibility**: Some people are simply more susceptible to seizures during certain brain states. This could be due to a variety of biological factors.

It's important to remember that everyone's experience with epilepsy is unique, and what triggers seizures can vary greatly from person to person. If you're finding that your seizures are primarily happening when you're tired, it might be helpful to:

- Maintain a consistent sleep schedule
- Ensure you're getting enough good quality sleep
- Speak with your healthcare provider about your sleep patterns and your medication
- Consider keeping a seizure diary to track when your seizures occur and what circumstances seem to trigger them

10.question: 31F, Caucasian, hx of chronic pain, anxiety, depression, CPTSD and Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.Last summer, I went in for a simple o/p procedure that was just supposed to be under mild sedation. I brought specific directions from my neurologist for medication protocols. However, I was met with a combative and rude anesthesiologist that decided he knew better, changed my plan, and ultimately induced me with propofol which was both stated and written to have caused me seizures in the past.I am missing a window of time for nearly 3 hours where I apparently had a cluster of seizures in the recovery ward. Eventually, they decided to contact my neurologist as well as my partner, both of which stated I needed to be given lorazepam to stop the seizures. They were getting ready to transport me via ambulance to the ER when I came around, absolutely freaked out and somewhat incoherent. My partner arrived as quickly as he could and all I said is I wanted to go home, so they allowed me to sign myself out and he took me home, not being told outright how bad things really went. I ultimately was able to request my records and went on to report the anesthesiologist.Ever since then, I haven’t been the same. My neurologists office has been indifferent to my situation. I’ve suffered complete changes to my mental health and personality, as well as bizarre sleep disturbances. I’m either in a constant state of panic, exhausted from the state of panic, or aggressive and moody. I wake up almost every night between 3-3:30am completely alert and ended up wandering around or on my phone for 1-2 hours until I pass back out. I was also having some breakthrough seizures in my sleep.Current meds: escitalopram 15mg q24 (recent increase) lacosamide 200mg q12 gabapentin 400mg q8-12 buspirone 5mg q12 (new) tizanidine 2-4mg before bed celecoxib 100mg q12-24 Vyvanse 30mg as needed (which I did quit for a while to see if it was the culprit. No change)Failed meds: temazepam venlafaxine lorazepam apriprazoleI just want my life back. I’m under the care of a new mental health facility because I felt like the last one wasn’t taking me seriously. Going to work or school is nearly impossible and I cry several times per day along with multiple panic attacks. We’ve considered an IOP or inpatient hospitalization if this isn’t under control soon.
10.answer:
I'm really sorry to hear about what you've been through and how much your life has been impacted by this experience. It's crucial to address this situation with a multidisciplinary team of professionals who can help you navigate both the physical and psychological consequences. Here's how you might approach this:

1. **Neurological Follow-up**: First, ensure you're closely monitoring your neurological health. Increase communication with your neurologist about the changes in your mental health and any new or increasing seizure activity. They should be aware of the recent event and its potential impact on your epilepsy.

2. **Psychiatric Evaluation**: Consult a psychiatrist, preferably one experienced in trauma and/or neurological conditions. They can help determine if the changes in your mental health are a result of traumatic stress (PTSD), another mental health condition, or a combination. They can also help optimize your medication regimen in conjunction with your neurologist.

3. **Therapy**: Consider both individual and group therapy. A therapist can help you process the trauma, manage anxiety and depression, and develop coping skills for panic attacks. Group therapy can provide a safe space to share experiences with others who understand what you're going through.

4. **Sleep Hygiene and Management**: Poor sleep can exacerbate mental health issues. Implement good sleep habits and consider talking to your healthcare provider about safe sleep medications or other strategies to improve sleep.

5. **Pain Management**: Since you have a history of chronic pain, ensure that your pain is being well-managed. Poorly controlled pain can also exacerbate mental health symptoms.

6. **Legal Counsel**: If you haven't already, consider consulting with an attorney about the incident with the anesthesiologist. They can help you understand your rights and potential recourse, and can advocate for better care and compensation.

7. **Support Groups**: Joining support groups for people with similar experiences (e.g., epilepsy, trauma, chronic pain) can provide valuable insights, advice, and a sense of community.

8. **Inpatient/Outpatient Programs**: If your symptoms haven't eased, it might be time to consider inpatient or intensive outpatient programs. These can provide a more structured, supportive environment for healing.

Here are some specific medications to discuss with your healthcare provider:

- **Antidepressants**: Your current antidepressant (escitalopram) may be adequate, but other SSRIs or SNRIs might be worth trying if you're not seeing improvement.
- **Anxiolytics**: Low-dose benzodiazepines or non-benzodiazepine anxiolytics can help manage anxiety. However, it's important to use them judiciously due to potential for dependency and interaction with other medications.
- **Antipsychotics**: Low-dose antipsychotics might be beneficial if you're experiencing mood instability or psychotic symptoms.
- **Anticonvulsants**: Given your history of seizures, it's worth discussing with your neurologist whether your current antiepileptic medications (lacosamide, gabapentin) are appropriate and well-tolerated.
- **Antipsychotics and Anticonvulsants**: Some medications, such as lamotrigine or carbamazepine, have mood-stabilizing properties and could be helpful in stabilizing your mood.

Lastly, be persistent and patient with yourself. Recovery takes time, and it's normal to have setbacks. But with the right support and care, it's possible to improve and reclaim your quality of life.

11.question: I have 2 conditions(?) i want to mention, the second being (in my opinion) more severe than the first.the first is something ive noticed more recently. im not sure how long its been going on. i got an apple watch in december, which is the first heart rate tracking device ive owned. ive been using it to occasionally measure my heartrate, and ive noticed that my resting heart rate lies anywhere from 20-50 or 60 bpm lower than my standing heart rate. for a while, immediately upon standing i would become dizzy and my vision would fade a little, and i would see spots. this usually clears up after around 10 seconds 20 seconds at the most. ive seen a lot of resources about pots but i dont and have never fainted or started sweating due to standing the second is something i can give a lot more details on. ive been calling these "blackouts" but thats not medically accurate. it usually starts with me feeling unusually sick for a bit, then suddenly, the sickness symptoms will instantly disappear and my hearing will muffle greatly, and my ears will start ringing, but the ringing is also muffled. then, my field of vision will begin to tunnel, gradually getting smaller and smaller, until it becomes completely black, at which point i lose all recollection of what im doing, im basically acting without being conscious.these started when i was 8 and have happened every few years or so since, with them gradually getting worse and worse. the first time it happened, it was just slight lightheadedness and nausea, then muffled hearing and my vision partially tunneling, but not going all the way. this more recent time a little less than 2 years ago, however, i felt extremely nauseous, i felt extremely cold yet i was sweating profusely, i think i might have had a headache too i cant fully remember. i felt like i was gonna die before the "blackout" even started and the muffled hearing started. when i fully blacked out and lost consciousness (while still controlling my body, like a zombie in a sense), i have no idea how long i was out for, and i only was brought back to reality when i felt water hit my foot after i knocked over a pitcher.ive done a lot of research on this specifically and the closest thing ive found has been transient ischemic attacks. im not fully sure if this is a tia though, especially because i cant recall weakness in one side of my body at any time during one of these, but that might be because my memory during these events isnt really the best. additionally, my moms biological mom had several strokes before dying of another stroke, which could make me more predisposed to strokes, but again im not entirely sure. ive also gotten results for certain types of epilepsy, but i never looked too deep into them so that may not be validthe reason i bring these two afflictions up together is because maybe im missing something? maybe these are both signs of a rare illness or something? maybe theyre two different things that are co morbid? they may have nothing to do with each other at all though, i just want to include anything i can think of some other things i have are a heat sensitivity (not sure if this is the correct term, but basically i just get really really hot for no reason and cant cool off until i put cold water on my body), as well as sweating a lot, like ill be cold and still sweating. not sure if these have anything to do with the above but im adding it here just in case.if you have any questions feel free to ask, theres something i may have forgotten to add here. also im sorry about the length, i have a tendency to explain things with a lot more words than are needed
11.answer:
Thank you for providing such detailed information. It's clear that you've done significant research and self-reflection on your symptoms. It's always best to consult with a healthcare provider for a professional medical opinion, but I can help you understand some possibilities based on the information you've provided.

1. **Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)**: Your first set of symptoms, where your heart rate increases significantly upon standing, along with dizziness and visual disturbances, could indicate POTS. This is a condition that affects circulation (blood flow), and it's often associated with other conditions like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, POTS often affects young women and can be triggered by factors like stress, dehydration, and changes in posture.

   - *Symptoms*: Apart from the increased heart rate and dizziness, other symptoms can include:
     - Fatigue
     - Excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis)
     - Heat intolerance
     - Headaches
     - Tremors/Shakiness
     - Nausea/vomiting
     - Brain fog
     - Sleep disturbances
     - Anxiety/exacerbation of symptoms with stress

   Some of these symptoms, like heat intolerance and excessive sweating, also match the additional symptoms you mentioned.

2. **Transient Ischemic Attacks (TIAs)**: Your second set of symptoms, which you've described as "blackouts", could indicate TIAs. These are temporary periods of decreased blood supply to the brain, often due to a blood clot. They can cause a variety of symptoms, and weakness on one side of the body is indeed one of the most common. However, it's possible that you're not experiencing that specific symptom, and it could be one of the others, such as:
   - Difficulty speaking or understanding speech
   - Numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body
   - Vision problems in one or both eyes
   - Vertigo (spinning sensation)
   - Loss of coordination
   - Sudden severe headache with no known cause

   The fact that these episodes have been occurring since you were 8, and seem to be becoming more severe over time, could also be a red flag for some underlying issue.

3. **Relation between the two conditions**: It's possible that these conditions are independent of each other. However, given that they both affect circulation and have some overlapping symptoms, it's also possible that they're related or even part of a larger picture. Further investigation is needed to determine this.

4. **Family history**: Your mother's biological mother's history of strokes is relevant information. There can be a genetic risk factor here, and it's worth exploring further.

5. **Other possibilities**: While you mentioned that you've explored some possibilities related to your second set of symptoms, it's still important to consider other potential causes. These could include:
   - Vasovagal syncope: Fainting due to a misunderstanding by your body's nervous system of its current state. It can lead to a decrease in blood pressure and heart rate, which can then lead to fainting.
   - Mitral valve prolapse: A heart condition where one of the heart's valves doesn't close properly.
   - Some form of seizure disorder: While you mentioned that you've looked into this, it's still worth discussing with a healthcare provider.

In conclusion, while your two sets of symptoms potentially point to different conditions, it's essential to consider the possibility that they're interconnected. Given the progressive nature of your second set of symptoms and your family history, it's crucial to seek professional medical evaluation. A healthcare provider can consider all your symptoms together and order appropriate tests to arrive at a diagnosis.

Lastly, it's commendable that you've taken the initiative to learn about your symptoms. However, it's important to remember that while self-research can be helpful, it should complement, not replace, professional medical advice. Please consult with a healthcare provider soon for further guidance.

12.question: 18M 72kg/160lbs 180cm healthy non-smoker and non-drinker. My blood pressure normally around 55/110 and my mother has epilepsy. I hyperventilated for some reason and stood up, passed out and woke up. I had a little dream when I passed out. My friend who was with me said I was swinging my right leg and scraping the carpet with my right hand for about 10 seconds. I remember scratching the carpet unintentionally for about 2 seconds. I'm feeling a little foggy. It happened a few hours ago. Was it an epileptic seizure or something else?
12.answer:
Given your family history of epilepsy, it's understandable that you're concerned about the possibility of a seizure. However, a single episode, especially with such brief unusual movements and a lack of consciousness or awareness during the event, doesn't necessarily indicate epilepsy. Epilepsy is typically characterized by recurring seizures, not a single episode. Here are a few possibilities:

1. **Vasovagal Syncope**: This is a common cause of fainting. It occurs when there's a brief interruption in blood flow to the brain, often due to stress, pain, prolonged standing, or hyperventilation. The hyperventilation could be the trigger in your case. Symptoms may include a brief episode of loss of consciousness, and in some cases, brief, involuntary muscle jerks or movements similar to what you described.

2. **Transient Loss of Consciousness (T-LOC)**: This can also result from brief interruptions in blood flow to the brain, similar to syncope. It's often caused by the same factors as syncope and can also be preceded by hyperventilation.

3. **Partial Seizure**: While less likely, given the brevity of the event and your awareness during part of it, it's possible you experienced a simple partial seizure. These typically involve brief, unusual movements or sensations in a small area of the body. However, they would not typically involve loss of consciousness.

Given your family history, it's important to speak with a healthcare provider about this episode. They may recommend further evaluation to rule out any neurological conditions. In the meantime, it may be helpful to:

- Try to avoid situations that trigger hyperventilation if possible.
- Practice slow, controlled breathing if you feel yourself becoming short of breath or anxious.
- If you experience another episode, try to lie down safely and gradually resume activities once you feel well.

Again, while it's important to consider epilepsy given your family history, it's also crucial to explore other possible causes of this episode. A thorough evaluation by a healthcare provider will help provide the most accurate diagnosis.

13.question: Female, 47, 65kg, 1.62cm, no other medicine or illness until thus far. No smoke, drinking, children or cases in the family.Up until I was 7 I took Gardenal. Then stopped - and my late granduncle was the top pediatric neurologist in the country - and did EEGs yearly until about 25.Had deja-vus up until college, never thought they could be considered related to epilepsy.When I was 45, epidemic, worst job in the world. Colleagues were in Rio, London, Lagos and Dubai. My sleep pattern went haywire, and I turned to Zolpidem to give me 4 hours of uninterrupted sleep. Started at 5mg. As pressure grew, isolation, trouble in the job, slowly I grew the dosage. Had a burnout, left the job, and now I was taking 500mg to 600mg a day. Yes, 2 to 3 boxes. A day. I was floating in mid-air, barely ever lucid.Then I started having tonic-clonics. 8 in few months. I was deeply scared and built a team of therapist, psychologist and neurologist. Good news, nothing physical in the brain. Other good news is that I quit Zolpidem cold turkey, had withdrawal, suffered a lot... But quit.
13.answer:
It's commendable that you sought help and took steps to address your situation. Here's a summary of your health history and the recommendations you might want to consider:

**Medical History:**
- Age: 47
- Sex: Female
- Height: 1.62 cm
- Weight: 65 kg
- No other medicine or illness until recently
- No smoking or drinking, no children or epilepsy cases in the family
- Took Gardenal (a brand of carbamazepine, an antiepileptic drug) until age 7 for undetermined reasons
- Regular EEGs until around 25, with no significant findings
- Experienced déjà vu episodes until college, now understood they might be related to potential epilepsy

**Current Situation:**
- Severe Zolpidem (Ambien) misuse due to work-related stress and burnout
- Dosage: 500mg to 600mg per day (2-3 boxes)
- Experiencing tonic-clonic seizures (8 in a few months)

**Next Steps and Recommendations:**

1. **Epilepsy evaluation**: Since you've experienced tonic-clonic seizures, it's crucial to undergo a thorough epilepsy evaluation. This might involve:
   -MRI scan to rule out any structural abnormalities in the brain
   -Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to check for infections or other conditions that might cause seizures
   -24-hour EEG to monitor brain activity for signs of seizure activity
   -Blood tests to check for underlying conditions that may be causing seizures

2. **Mental health support**: Continue working with your therapist and psychologist to manage stress, anxiety, and depression that may be triggered by the seizure events and the changes in your life.

3. **Sleep management**: Address your sleep problems without relying on medication. Consider Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), which is a proven Effective non-medication approach to manage insomnia.

4. **Gradual detoxification**: If you haven't already, work with your healthcare provider to gradually reduce and stop Zolpidem use under medical supervision to minimize withdrawal symptoms.

5. **Antiepileptic medication**: If test results indicate epilepsy as the cause of your seizures, your neurologist may prescribe antiepileptic drugs to prevent further seizures.

6. **Epilepsy self-management education**: Learn about epilepsy, seizure first aid, and how to manage your condition to improve your quality of life.

It's essential to work closely with your healthcare team to address these issues and find the best treatment plan tailored to your needs. Take care of your physical and mental health, and remember that recovery is a journey that takes time and effort.

14.question: I (30F) had a seizure for the first time 3 days ago. I had had a couple beers, smoked a joint, and did some shrooms (none of which is unusual for me). I have no family history of epilepsy, and am in generally good health.I was checked out by paramedics immediately after the seizure who said I looked fine and it was probably from the shrooms. I went to my PCP the next day and she ordered a couple blood tests which all came back normal. I am waiting for brain imaging to be approved by my insurance.Now it’s three days later and I still feel exhausted and weak and slow. I could barely get through my workday today. Is this normal? Is extreme fatigue indicative of something?Also I don’t know if it’s relevant at all but about a month ago I started experiencing extreme nausea to the point I was calling off sick at work, vomiting in the middle of the day, and had just had a doctors appointment to discuss that the week before.
14.answer:
It is not uncommon to feel fatigued, weak, and slow for a few days after a first-time seizure. Your body goes through a lot during a seizure, and it's typical to feel the effects for a short time afterward. However, since you're still experiencing these symptoms days after the event, it's understandable that you're concerned.

The extreme fatigue could be due to several reasons:

1. **Recovery from the seizure**: As mentioned, your body has been through a lot, and it needs time to recover.

2. **Stress and anxiety**: A seizure can be a very stressful and anxiety-inducing event. These emotions can also contribute to feelings of fatigue.

3. **Medications**: Even if your doctor hasn't prescribed any new medications yet, some over-the-counter pain relievers or other medications you're taking could be causing fatigue as a side effect.

4. **Hydration and nutrition**: After a seizure, it's important to pay extra attention to staying hydrated and eating well. If you're not doing so, it could contribute to your fatigue.

As for your history of nausea, it's important to note that some medications used to treat seizures can also cause nausea as a side effect. It's possible that your recent symptoms are related. It's also possible that the two events are unrelated, and you may have an underlying condition causing both issues.

Given your recent history of nausea and the unusual nature of your seizure (as a first-time event), it's crucial to follow up with your healthcare provider. Here's what you should do:

1. **Keep a seizure diary**: Track your seizures, noting when they happen, what you were doing, how long they last, and any other details. This can help your doctor determine if there are any patterns or triggers.

2. **Inform your doctor**: Share your ongoing symptoms and concerns with your primary care physician. They can help determine if there's an underlying issue that needs to be addressed.

3. **Get brain imaging done**: As you mentioned, you're waiting for brain imaging to be approved. This is an essential step in determining the cause of your seizure. If approved, ensure you get this done as soon as possible.

4. **Consider seeing a neurologist**: If your primary care physician feels it's necessary, or you're still concerned after discussing with them, ask for a referral to a neurologist, who specializes in conditions of the brain and nervous system.

In the meantime, make sure you're taking care of yourself. This includes getting plenty of rest, staying hydrated, eating well, and avoiding substances like alcohol and marijuana, as they can interfere with any potential seizure medications you may be prescribed.

15.question: 33f/5’3”/185lbs/no major health issuesWhat I’ve been experiencing: Out of nowhere my eyes get super sensitive to light. I will get an overwhelming sensation of doom/panic. My body basically forgets how to breathe. Heart rate goes up. My brain feels weird, dizzy, and fuzzy. I get hot and nauseous. I just don’t feel ok, something in my head just feels very off and I’m scared. These episodes last for a few seconds to a few minutes. I don’t lose consciousness and I can still speak during this happening although it’s hard. Sometimes after I feel tired and sometimes I feel normal. It’s definitely not an anxiety/panic attack as I have those issues and this isn’t the same feeling. I’ve also been experiencing more headaches lately. Tinnitus. Eyesight is just very weird and sensitive all the time with floaters. My short term memory isn’t great anymore. Reading out loud is getting harder. Weird muscle twitches below my lip/chin area. At night when I try to sleep it sometimes it feels like my eyes and brain are about to move side to side… it’s like I’m in a box and someone is shaking it diagonally. Makes me dizzy as all hell and my body feels it too. That has happened a handful of times in my life in the past and I went years without it happening and it’s back, and it’s scary and feels horrible. Shaking my head hard helps stop it when I feel it coming on.Does what I’m experiencing sound like focal seizure/epilepsy? I’m really nervous about this. I’m wondering if it’s all because of the trazodone or if I had this since I was a kid (since I’ve experienced that weird shaking in a box sensation multiple times through my life) and the trazodone made it all come to the surface?Meds I take: klonopin 1mg, vitamin d, probiotic, melatonin 2mg, trazodone 25mg.
15.answer:
Based on the symptoms you've described, it's understandable that you're concerned and I encourage you to consult with a healthcare professional for a thorough evaluation. Here's a breakdown of your symptoms and their potential correlations with neurological conditions, including focal seizures:

1. **Light sensitivity, panic, and altered breathing**: These symptoms could indicate a photophobic episode, a type of aura that sometimes precede focal seizures, but they can also be associated with migraines or other non-epileptic conditions.

2. **Increased heart rate, dizziness, and nausea**: These symptoms can accompany various conditions, including panic attacks, vertigo, migraine aura, or even hypoglycemia.

3. **Brain fog, fuzzy thinking, and memory issues**: While these symptoms could be related to anxiety or stress, they might also indicate a neurological issue like a focal seizure with cognitive or affective features, or a non-epileptic attack disorder.

4. **Headaches and tinnitus**: These symptoms are common and can be associated with various conditions, including migraines, which can sometimes occur independently or in combination with epilepsy.

5. ** Floaters, blurred vision, and eye discomfort**: These symptoms could point towards eye health issues, migraines, or certain neurological conditions.

6. **Muscle twitches**: This can be a normal occurrence or a sign of various conditions, including anxiety, stress, or certain neurological disorders.

7. **Nighttime shaking sensation**: The feeling of being in a box and shaken diagonally could be a form of vertigo, a Neurological symptom that can be related to inner ear disorders, or possibly an atypical seizure manifestation.

Regarding your medications:

- **Trazodone**: While it's unlikely that this antidepressant would cause focal seizures, it's always possible for medication to unmask pre-existing vulnerabilities or trigger neurological symptoms in some individuals. It can also cause various side effects, including dizziness, headaches, and cognitive impairment.

- **Klonopin (clonazepam)**: This anti-anxiety medication is generally well-tolerated but can also cause side effects such as drowsiness, dizziness, and memory problems.

It's essential to consider that having multiple symptoms doesn't necessarily confirm a seizure disorder. A thorough evaluation by a neurologist will help clarify your concerns. This may involve:

- A detailed medical history and physical examination
- Brain imaging (e.g., MRI) to examine your brain's structure
- Electroencephalogram (EEG) to assess your brain's electrical activity

Be sure to discuss your concerns with your healthcare provider, and don't hesitate to bring this list of symptoms for a more accurate assessment. They can help determine if your symptoms are due to an underlying medical condition, a side effect of your medications, or a combination of factors.

16.question: UK female 40 162cm 77kgs no smoking, alcohol or drugsDiagnosis of autism, asthma, Ehlers Danlos type 1 and presumed epilepsyMedication is Levetiracetam 1250mg twice a day and Fostair inhalers and cetirizine over the counterRecently had an EEG for nocturnal episodes of unilateral clonic and tonic movements lasting 20 to 160 seconds witnessed by partner and on video plus brief (30 sec max) daytime episodes of twitching and ‘swooping’ sensation in head - all improved but not stopped by Levetiracetam. MRI and CT scans normal. Neurolgist reported on EEH as ’essentially normal’ with no other details, but has advised GP diagnosis is presumed epilepsy however described it as a difficult case to diagnose. My question is why would he describe the EEG as ‘essentially normal’ rather than just normal?
16.answer:
A neurologist might describe an EEG as "essentially normal" rather than just "normal" for several reasons, even when there are clear abnormal events occurring. Here are a few possibilities, given the context you've provided:

1. **Non-specific Abnormalities**: The EEG might have shown non-specific abnormalities, such as small sharp spikes (SSS) or wicket spikes, which are not typically associated with epilepsy. These can appear in people with and without epilepsy, so they're considered non-specific. While these abnormalities might be 'essentially normal' in terms of not being diagnostic of epilepsy, they could be relevant in your partner's case.

2. **Intermittent Nature**: Epileptic activity on an EEG can be intermittent, meaning it doesn't occur all the time. This can make it harder to capture on a single EEG test. The fact that your partner's episodes improved but did not stop with Levetiracetam suggests that the EEG might not have captured the abnormal activity during the test.

3. **Sleep deprivation**: EEGs are sometimes done after a period of sleep deprivation to increase the likelihood of capturing abnormal activity. If this wasn't done, or if your partner didn't respond to the sleep deprivation, this could be another reason for a 'normal' EEG.

4. **Other Factors**: There could be other factors at play that make the EEG less sensitive or specific. For instance, certain medications (like Levetiracetam) can affect the results, as can noise interference and physiological artifacts.

Given the above points, the neurologist might have been exercising caution in their interpretation of the EEG and acknowledging that while it might not show clear evidence of epilepsy, it doesn't completely rule it out either. It's important to note that the diagnosis of epilepsy often relies on a combination of factors, including clinical history, physical examination, and EEG findings.

Given your partner's history of errichtete events, and the neurologist's advice to continue with Levetiracetam despite a 'normal' EEG, it's likely that they are considering other diagnoses or epilepsy subtypes that might not be fully captured by a standard EEG. In any case, it's always a good idea to discuss these findings with the neurologist directly, as they have the most comprehensive understanding of your partner's case.

17.question: I want to donate plasma, partially because I have O negative blood and would be available every 4 weeks to donate. And partially because I discovered donating plasma also has health benefits for the donors such as reducing micro-plastics in the body.From what I can see online in the UK if you’re epileptic you can’t donate plasma/blood. I was wondering if anyone knew the reason for this? Is it because the medication I take could cause issues if it was in the blood?Or is it more of a ‘we’re worried you may have a seizure while donating’ kind of risk where a doctors note might mitigate risks?If it’s the latter, it seems a shame that something which could have a positive impact for both parties isn’t allowed so I just wanted some insight into the matter as I can’t see anything online which actually talks about the reasons behind the restriction.Female, 27, Epileptic, medication: Keppra and Eslicarbazepine, other than being epileptic I am healthy in all other respects (BMI: 20, non-smoker, non-drinker)
17.answer:
The decision to accept or decline a blood or plasma donation from an individual is based on guidelines established by regulatory bodies, such as the NHS Blood and Transplant in the UK, to ensure the safety of both the donor and the recipient. These guidelines are informed by scientific research and expert medical advice.

There are several reasons why people with epilepsy may be temporarily deferred or permanently deferred from donating blood or plasma:

1. **Safety of the donor**: During the donation process, donors are connected to a machine that withdraws blood, separates the plasma, and returns the red blood cells to the donor. If a donor has a seizure during this process, it could be dangerous for both the donor and the medical staff involved. Even if you have well-controlled epilepsy with no recent history of seizures, the risk cannot be completely ruled out.

2. **Safety of the recipient**: The use of anti-epileptic medication could introduce potential contaminants or altered properties into the donated plasma, posing a risk to the recipient. While it's true that medication can be filtered out during the processing of plasma, there's still a risk of trace amounts remaining in the final product.

3. **Seizure-triggers**: Certain aspects of the donation process might potentially trigger a seizure in a person with epilepsy, even if they have not had a seizure in a long time. For example, the tubing used for plasma donation can feel cold, and some donors may experience lightheadedness during or after donation.

It is worth noting that these restrictions are not unique to the UK; similar restrictions apply in many other countries as well. The decision to impose these restrictions is not taken lightly and is based on a desire to maximize the safety and benefits of blood and plasma donation for both donors and recipients.

While it is understandable that you might feel frustrated or disappointed by these restrictions, it's crucial to remember that the primary concern of regulatory bodies is the safety and well-being of those involved in the donation process. If the guidelines were to change in the future, and you were to be medically cleared to donate, you could certainly consider doing so.

It might be helpful to speak with your neurologist or a representative from the NHS Blood and Transplant organization to gain a more detailed understanding of the reasons behind these restrictions and whether there are any circumstances under which you might be able to donate in the future. They can provide you with the most accurate and up-to-date information based on your specific medical situation.

18.question: My friend is 19 and pregnant. She’s in her 11th week of pregnancy and started experiencing “seizures” while sleeping and then also while awake. so she admitted to the hospital but the doctors couldn’t figure out what’s wrong. She doesn’t have any history of epilepsy or seizures even in her family. she did experience sepsis about a couple months ago while she was pregnant with her last baby (she had to abort it). This time around apparently just her magnesium levels were low in the blood tests and her oxygen saturation levels were around 93% when she would start getting dizzy and about to experience a “seizure”. I say “seizure” because apparently the docs at the hospital didn’t think they were proper seizures and ive never seen one of hers so idk either but she would experience amnesia after them, be very confused and dazed. She also wouldn’t experience any pain during the seizures but would afterwards when she came out of them. I’m only really looking for advice.
18.answer:
It's understandable that you're concerned about your friend's health and the well-being of her unborn child. Here are some steps you can take to support her and help her find answers:

1. **Keep a detailed record**: Encourage your friend to keep a diary or use an app to record the incidents, noting down the time, any preceding events, how long each episode lasted, and her behavior before, during, and after. This will provide valuable information for her healthcare team.

2. **Seek specialist opinion**: It might be helpful to consult with a neurologist or an epileptologist (a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy) who has experience with pregnancy-related seizures. Some hospitals or clinics may have epilepsy pregnancy registries, which can provide useful information and monitoring.

3. **Consider alternative diagnoses**: While the episodes your friend is experiencing may seem like seizures, it's important to explore other possible causes, especially given her history of sepsis and the details of the episodes (like amnesia, confusion, and lack of pain during the event). Other conditions to consider can include:

   - **Synchronal brigade**: This is a rare condition where a person feels dizzy or faints, but it's not a true seizure.

   - **Severe migraine aura**: Aura is a set of symptoms that can occur before or with a migraine. In some cases, it can cause disorientation, confusion, or changes in vision.

   - **Conversion disorder or dissociative disorders**: These conditions can cause seizures-like episodes, often triggered by stress or emotional factors.

4. **Rule out electrolyte imbalances**: Low magnesium levels were noted, but your friend should also be tested for other electrolyte imbalances, such as low sodium levels (hyponatremia), which can sometimes cause seizures and confusion.

5. **Eclampsia or eclamptic seizure**: Although unlikely at this stage of pregnancy, eclampsia involves seizures that can happen suddenly after 20 weeks of gestation in women with preeclampsia. The key features of preeclampsia include high blood pressure and damage to organs such as the liver and kidneys. Your friend should be closely monitored for signs of preeclampsia.

6. **Prenatal care**: Ensure your friend is receiving regular prenatal care and that her pregnancy is being closely monitored. Any issues with the pregnancy (like growth restriction, preeclampsia, or other complications) can sometimes manifest as unusual symptoms.

7. **Support and encouragement**: Offer emotional support and encourage your friend to prioritize her health and follow her healthcare team's advice. Remind her that it's okay to ask for help and to advocate for herself.

19.question: 22F, 110 poundsCurrent Medications- Lamictal 200 mg in the AM & PM so 400mg total a day. Vyvanse 40mg once a day, don't take on the weekends unless I am scheduled to work.I smoke medical marijuana and HARDLY drink, probably 3 times year.Background- So I need to say now that when I was explained all of this I was 16 so it is very dumbed down and I still do not fully understand it lol. But when I was 15 I took 47 coricidin cough and cold pills and was not breathing by the time EMS arrived. I was intubated for about three weeks and once I began being able to breathe on my own it was clear I was in some form of psychosis. I was ripping IV's out, biting nurses, running down the halls and a lot more crazy shit. My dad recorded some of these breakouts and its actually horrifying to see because for me it is all black. I don't remember any of it. I simply took the pills and woke up 2 months later in a mental hospital confused as shit. I believe I had dextromethorphan toxicity. Anyway fast forward 6 months and I had my first seizure. I have grand Mal seizures where I full on flop. They usually last about 2 minutes and my Husband (he saw my first seizure and pretty much every one since then) says that before I start full on seizing I become real quiet and look up to my left. After doing all of the tests (sleep test, EEG & MRI) my neurologist explain to me that there was a lesion in my brain with secretions firing off and if they fire off at the right time I have a seizure. Then more recently I had a newer MRI done where my neurologist said there was only a tiny possible lesion? I dont understand how it would get smaller? I still have seizures if I do not take my medication. I actually think I have more now because if I miss one dose Ill have a seizure, whereas as a teenager I was shit about taking my medications and did not have near as many seizures.So my questions is could my lesion be shrinking and if so would my seizures stop?
19.answer:
It's really important to understand that what you've experienced and are going through is serious, and you should always follow your doctor's advice. Based on the information you've provided, here are some points to consider, along with your questions:

1. **Seizures and Lesions:** The information about the lesion in your brain is somewhat confusing. In some types of epilepsy, lesions (such as scars, tumors, or areas of brain damage) can be the cause of seizures. However, it's not typical for these lesions to shrink over time. It's possible that the earlier MRI findings were interpreted differently in your recent MRI, or there could have been a mistake in the reporting. It's crucial to discuss this with your neurologist, as accurate information about the cause of your seizures is important for managing them.

2. **Medication Adherence:** You mentioned that you have more seizures now when you miss a dose. This could be due to age (seizures can become more frequent as you get older), stress, or other factors, but it's also possible that it's because you're more consistent with your medication now. When you were younger and not taking your meds regularly, you might have had more seizures than you remember.

3. **Will your seizures stop if the lesion is shrinking?** Even if the lesion in your brain is shrinking, that doesn't necessarily mean your seizures will stop. The relationship between the size of the lesion and the frequency of your seizures is complex and can be influenced by many factors. It's possible that even a small lesion can still cause seizures, depending on its location and the way your brain is wired.

4. **Understanding your Condition:** It's completely normal to not fully understand your condition when you were first explained it at 16. It's always a good idea to ask your neurologist for more information or to go through it again. They can explain it in a way that's easier for you to understand.

Here are some tips moving forward:

- Always take your medication as prescribed. Missing doses increases the risk of seizures.
- Keep in touch with your neurologist. Regular appointments can help monitor your condition and make adjustments to your treatment as needed.
- If you have any changes in your health or lifestyle, let your neurologist know. This could include things like starting a new job, moving, getting pregnant, or changes in your sleep patterns, all of which can affect seizure frequency.
- Write down your questions before your appointments. This can help you remember what you want to ask and ensure you leave feeling informed.

20.question: 40 years old, 10 stone (140 pounds)Epilepsy-Asthma-Thyroid-Scoliosis-Bladder conditionMeds: Epilim chrono 500mg, Epilim 200mg, Etanercept, Ventolin, LevothyroxineI take one 200mg Epilim pill in the morning and two 500mg ones in the evening. In the morning I take the 200mg pill with my breakfast fine, but when I take the 500mg tablet after dinner, I swallow the tablet with water like in the morning, I'm coughing up the water and the pill is getting lodged in my throat. This has been happening every other day in the last 2 weeks.I'm coughing up phelgmn and I've tried warm water to force the pill down as it is a enteric-coated pill, which reacts with water straight away. The longer the pill stays in my throat, it scrapes my throat and blood comes out with my spit. My throat is sore afterwards which takes two days to recover. I have to take my Epilepsy pills for life.I'm afraid to keep taking the 500ml tablets in the evening, as I keep having this reaction.Should I take 5 of the 200mg pills instead to make up the 1000mg required in the evening which are easier to swallow or do something else?I'm going to speak to my pharmacist and GP tomorrow morning as well about it.
20.answer:
It's great that you're planning to talk to your healthcare professionals about this issue. In the meantime, here are some suggestions that might help, but please note that this is not medical advice and you should always follow the advice of your doctor or pharmacist:

1. **Change in Administration:** Instead of taking your evening dose of Epilim with dinner, you might try taking it about an hour or two after eating, with a full glass of water (around 8 ounces). The full glass of water can help to rinse the pill down more easily.

2. **Take with a Rrology Beverage:** Some people find it easier to swallow tablets with a thicker liquid like yogurt, applesauce, or even a spoonful of peanut butter. However, Epilim's enteric coating is designed to dissolve in the small intestine, not in your stomach, so it's best to avoid liquids or foods that could dissolve the coating.

3. **Split the Dosage:** If you find the 500mg tablet hard to swallow, it might be worth asking your doctor if you can split the dose. You could take your 200mg tablet in the morning as usual, and then split the 1000mg into two 500mg doses in the evening. This might make it easier to swallow each dose.

4. **Take with a small amount of Food:** Taking medication with a small amount of food can sometimes help it go down more easily. However, this might not be suitable for your situation, as you're already taking the tablet in the evening after dinner.

Regarding your question about taking 5 of the 200mg tablets instead, you should discuss this with your doctor. They can help you determine if it's safe to split your dose or adjust the type of tablet you're taking. It's important to never change your medication dosage without first speaking to a healthcare professional.

Also, if you're coughing up phlegm and blood, and experiencing sore throat for a couple of days after taking the medication, these could be signs of an allergic reaction or an exacerbation of your existing condition. It's crucial to bring these symptoms to your doctor's attention as soon as possible.

In the meantime, make sure to stay hydrated and perhaps try gargling with warm salt water to soothe your throat. However, avoid using any remedies without first consulting with a healthcare professional, as they may interact with your medications.

21.question: 23F, 5'8, 134 lbs, medications: trokendi xr switching over to topiramate, nonsmoker, epileptic, no location, and no photo.Hello, my medication trokendi xr is currently on backorder, and my neurologist sent a new prescription in for some generic topiramate. The only question I did not get to ask him was if I have to continue only taking 1 a day since trokendi is an extended release or if I have to take 2 a day. Thanks!
21.answer:
Hello! It's great that you're following up on your medication questions. When switching from an extended-release formulation like Trokendi XR to an immediate-release formulation like generic Topiramate, the dosing frequency typically changes because the extended-release formulation is designed to release the medication slowly over time, while the immediate-release formulation releases it all at once.

Typically, you would need to take generic Topiramate twice a day (BID), usually once in the morning and once in the evening, to maintain the same amount of medication in your system as you would with Trokendi XR taken once a day. However, it's always crucial to consult with your healthcare provider for personalized advice, as they have the most up-to-date and complete information about your health and medication.

Here's a helpful breakdown:

- Trokendi XR: Taken once a day (QD)
- Generic Topiramate (immediate-release): Taken twice a day (BID)

22.question: Before I start of with everything I am diagnosed with BPD, epilepsy, anxiety, aura headaches, pcos, and vertigo. It started with me just getting vertigo in 2019 and it went away with medication but came back within a week and i got chest pains and went to see a cardiologist and everything was okay. I was then sent to a neurologist and they finally diagnosed me with epilepsy but I don't have seizures. for awhile though i was having episodes of "falling into the ground" feelings and if i was in the car it would feel like i was falling back. I would just get odd feelings like that. i was told i basically have micro seizures. there's times where i get dizzy and don't feel good or just don't feel right and im guessing it could just be depersonalization but I'm honestly not sure. l've been now struggling with a migraine for over a month now and i had a mri done that came out normal and im having another one and a mra done tomorrow to see if something looks off. I've been struggling with migraines for awhile but never like this. I'm honestly just hoping maybe someone has had a similar experience or a answer? idk I've been in so much painMedications: metaformin Aimoveg, only one shot so far venlafaxine bupropion Mag oxide ToprimateHeight; 5'7 Weight: 180 I only smoke sometimes , I never drink alcohol
22.answer:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through all these health issues, and I hope that the upcoming tests will provide some answers. Here's a summary of your situation and some information based on your symptoms and conditions:

1. **Vertigo and Microseizures:** You've been experiencing vertigo and what you describe as "falling into the ground" feelings, which your neurologist has attributed to microseizures.
